Posts.Content: Hiya, I would also go towards double mx if it was me.I only had single mx, didn't even consider double. There was only 11 days between dx and op, so didn't even think about it/ or know it was an option.  My cancer also did not show up on mammogram. US wasn't that great either, was told it looked like my nodes were clear, turns out 14 out of 18 contained cancer.  My only check up now is yearly mammo (actually just had my 2 year one today). I do wonder if there is much point, but I guess yes just in case something does show up.  For me, I did notice changes in my infected boob for 2 year prior to dx that drs dismissed so I think I have an idea what to look out for.  Also when I had my mri, I don't think they used a contrast dye. They definitely did for the ct scan, but not the mri.  Peace of mind is everything. Cwtches, Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hi I have used the cold cap now for 5 sessions. and I feel your pain!  Session 4 was awful. Before session 5, I took paracetamol and ibuprofen half an hour before starting the cap. You would not be a wimp, you have tried it out.  There's no shame in having a go at something. In fact part of me thinks it is braver to say had a go, didn't work out, not using it anymore, than to carry on and suffer! Take care, Gay xxx

I would wait till Tuesday, you might be feeling a bit better by then. But if it is worrying you, then give them a ring on Monday. Cwtches, Gay xxx

No other noticeable side effects that I am aware off. A bit stiff in the mornings but that is due to the letrozole I think. Cwtches, Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Cancelled appointment after 4 week wait.

Posts.Content: Hiya Coley1993, Fec chemo is made up of the drugs  fluorouracil (also called 5FU) epirubicin cyclophosphamide. Ec  chemo is epirubicin and cyclophosphamide. without the fluorouracil. Some hospital trusts think that the 'f' drug is not necessary and as it can have unpleasant side effects, they leave it out. Some hospital trusts however have left it in.  My eyebrows and eye lashes stayed put throughout fec, but I lost all my lashes and most of my brows on docetaxel (t).  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Soooo, Sorry that you are having to wait longer for your appointment. Unfortunately the 2 week wait for an urgent referral is not always met, and it can depend very much on whereabouts you live. I had to wait nearly 6 weeks for an urgent referral before I had my appointment at the breast clinic, despite my gp writing, 'I highly suspect this is bc.'  It is unfortunate that your appt was cancelled. Did they just cancel it and leave it, surely it would have made sense at the very least to make another appointment at the same time? I would give the gp and/or the hospital a ring on Monday to find out what is going on. Waiting is the absolute pits, whether for an appointment or for results. Hope you can get this sorted asap! Take care, Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Hiya lovely, I am not sure if you are scared of the scans or or the results, or maybe both. So let me say in terms of the scans first. I have had a ct, bone and mri (of the breasts). I have to say the mri scan was the most I was scared of. I absolutely hate being in confined spaces. But I let the technicians for the mri know this and they said I could stop at any time. They also said that my other half could be there if I wanted to hold my hand  - I said no, because I thought I would be calmer without him!!! (I didn't tell him this - he likes to think he is doing his best to support me -Ha, ha) One main thing though, it is very very noisy. Like you are in a washing machine doing full cycle and then the tumble drying! In terms of the results, I do understand how scary this is. Just think that as soon as or if they find something, they can offer treatment for it. It would be much worse if something was going on and wasn't detected. I know that sounds scary, I am in the same boat with you. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Spine MRI tomorrow can't eat, sleep, concentrate.

Posts.Content: Hi Butterflybaby, Welcome to the online forum. I was diagnosed with ILC last November and am now just about coming to the end of treatment. Mx with immediate recon, node clearance, chemo and radio. Just finished radiotherapy last week, although apparently you still cook for a couple of weeks after!! The time has gone so quick. I can't believe it! It has been nowhere near as bad as I expected it to be. My worry now is going back to work - I think I may have forgotten how to do it! The cold cap isn't all that bad, just uncomfortable and you look very silly! I used to take a couple of paracetamol half an hour before putting it on. I would take a cardie or jacket you can put over your shoulders if needed because I used to find that all of me felt cold. Take in some nice nibbles as a treat part way through. And using the cold cap will slightly extend the session so make sure you have things to keep you occupied eg kindle, tablet, book, magazine. Maybe take a cap/hat to wear leaving the hospital. You will have your hair plastered in conditioner and a few icicles too - not the best look! Best wishes for Tuesday, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: June 2017 Chemotherapy

Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Hi Butterflybaby, Overall I think I coped pretty well with chemo. With FEC (EC + another drug) I think the main side effect is usually nausea. I wore anti nausea travel bands from Boots ( I remembered that they took away my morning sickness when I was pregnant). I don't know if they helped, but I didn't suffer from nausea at all.  There are plenty of anti sickness meds if you do suffer from nausea. The steroids they give you for a couple of days after do keep you awake though.  Week 2 is when your white blood cells are a their lowest. Week 3  - completely back to normal. I would think that week 3 would be the best week to go away.  I then had the 3 weekly docetaxel which did cause more aches, days 3-8 so I had lots of painkillers at the ready.  The cold cap worked ok...I will say that I lost about half my hair, had some very dodgy bald patches but then longer hair that I could comb over. I have had my hair cut quite short now because it was all different lengths and in not great condition. But overall I would choose to wear it again if I needed to.  Try not to worry too much about Tuesday.  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: June 2017 Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hiya Carrie1974, Have to say waiting for results is really shit!!! On the positive side the statistics are in your favour so hopefully your stay on here might not be long.  Yes, it is well known on here that Dr Google is evil and if approached, must be handled with care. As well as the macmillan sites, cancer research and breast cancer care are also reputable sites that you could look at if you want to, but you might be jumping the gun at this stage.  I would say carry on your normal life as much as possible. Try to imagine a box at the back of your mind where you can store your worries away. Some people have said that they give themselves eg 30 mins a day to think about it and then they put it in the box. I also found going to work helped. Some of my close colleagues that I told, said what on earth are you coming into work for - but I had to, it kept my mind occupied. Try to get on with mundane things that will keep you occupied. Sort out summer/winter clothes, spring clean, change the beds, go to the cinema, go for a walk (but wrap up warm!). Remember worrying about it will not change the results - so there is no point worrying. My OH also didn't want to talk about it. I bent the ear of my sister in law who is a nurse and is very calming. Is there anyone else you could talk to? I didn't tell my mum or my children till I got my dx. If there isn't anybody, then come on here (there are other sites too) and cry, rant and get your worries out - regardless of the fact you haven't got a dx yet. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Refered to breast cminic

Posts.Content: Hi, Just wanted to wish you all the best for tomorrow. I had my first day back in school on Friday after being absent since last November. I did not actually teach any classes I had a day to catch up, find out where my classes were etc. I have two days this week and I will have classes. I am excited but do feel a little bit sick to my stomach when I think about it. I think it will be like riding a bike - once you get there it will all come flooding back, and it will feel like you have not been away!! The staff and pupils I saw on Friday were wonderful and I had loads of hugs. But I really understand how you are feeling. As Jo says, it did feel good to be back. Just getting up and putting on a teacher outfit (smart trousers and blouse , smart shoes etc) rather than slobby jeans and a t-shirt made me feel good, like the teacher me was still there. Are you not classified as still being employed whilst being on sick leave? Even though I have been off, I am still employed by the council so I would not think to put down any gaps on my CV (if I updated mine). The only snag would be if there was a section asking about how many days off sick in the past year. In my opinion to begin with I would not include it in the covering letter. I would just try to sell myself as much as possible and hope to get interviews. The only thing then is what would you say at the interview - why not speak to the workplace advisors on the helpline for advice on what you should declare and the best way to go about it?   Just take it nice and slow tomorrow, it will all come back and as already said, enjoy it! Gay xxx

Posts.Title: The results are in!

Posts.Content: Hi JustLittlleMe, I haven't had slb but I did have full node clearance on 23rd Nov so thought I would let you know about my experience and if it helps. It is not that painful, really just a persistent little ache but it is not that bad. I am aware of it but it is not too painful at all. I have been taking co codamol but it is only because I was given a big supply, and to be honest I am sure that I could cope without them. I am just a big wuss. I have been advised not to lift anything at all but sometimes I forget because it is my right hand side! Lifting doesn't hurt but I am worried about the risk of lympadema as I have no nodes left at all. I can easily move arm, but there are sets of exercises that you will be given to do, and I find it difficult to lift my arm out to the side. It doesn't hurt but I can feel it stretching. After 2 and a half weeks I did drive a very short journey but I live in a small village, I don't fancy driving around in a bigger place just in case. I do have to take my time getting dressed and I needed help to wash my hair. Clothes irritate the top of my arm and I can't sleep on my right hand side. Also not sure if it is just me but I look like I am developing a bingo wing!!! Can't help about how blue you will go though! xxx

Posts.Content: Hi, If there is a recurrence, then it may not necessarily be in the breast. It may spread to other parts of the body eg lungs, liver, bones. So in answer to your question, if you have a high chance of recurrence then a mx on a healthy breast would not be as effective as chemo. Also I don't think that many surgeons like performing surgery on a perfectly healthy breast - although it may be different in different parts of the country.  Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Waiting biopsy results!

Posts.Content: HI Crazycatlady26, Oh, I am from a little bit south of Carlisle - Lancaster. I used to drive past Carlisle on my way to Newcastle(A69). I did my teaching practice in a school in Kendal. With chemo. the day or so before you need to go and have your bloods tested and have appointment with onc. Then there is the chemo session itself and then the day after, you have an injection - I had to wait in for the district nurse to give mine. The second week after chemo is when your white blood cells are the lowest - I wouldn't go anywhere near school that week! I think that for teachers, it is generally recommended that they don't work through chemo.  I was devastated at first, really upset for my exam classes. But they got by fine without me! Damn thought I was indispensable - (only joking.) One of the other teachers at the school had bc in her early thirties. She was a font of knowledge through treatment. However you have us now on this forum so anything you need to know, fire away! Cwtches, Gay xxx

Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hiya, This is very much a personal decision, isn't it? Personally (I wasn't given a choice) I would opt for surgery first, which is what I had. Once I knew for definite what it was, I just wanted it out of me asap. I hated my boob, couldn't bear to touch it. But I had fairly small boobs and a relatively big tumour so I think that a mastectomy was always on the cards for me. Also lobular cancer (I had that too) seems to be a lot more sneakier than ductal cancer because of the way the tumour grows. Mine ended up being bigger than what I was told. Maybe someone will come along who had chemo first to give their opinion.  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn for your response.  I have given myself a good talking to! Trying to look forward and be positive.  I am very jealous of you running a mile 3x a week! I am very unfit. I think I should get myself doing more exercise, maybe this is the kick up the bum I needed! xxx
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Phaedra, and Mom74, I also piled on the pounds during chemo due to inactivity and tastebuds being all over the shop. Oh the fact that Easter eggs were on sale from jan to april also might have had something to do with it. Well I deserved a bit of a treat, didn't I? I would say don't worry about your weight during this time. I have now finished radiotherapy and started going to the gym and swimming. The pounds are slowly coming off. (not as quick as I would like mind!) Gracie ask your onc about whether you could use the cold cap. I used it with no problems. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: I can't stop thinking about this, in fact I am getting quite cross with myself. I just keep thinking I should focus on what's happening now, but my mind keeps wandering. I was referred by my GP and first saw a consultant about my breasts in the hospital in 2014. I had constant pain in my breasts, taking 4x2 lots of over the counter ibuprofen a day. This lasted for months. I could not feel a definite lump - I just thought that the whole thing felt lumpy anyway. I think this is why I was surprised this year when the doctor this year said I had a definite lump. It has always felt lumpy!!! My right breast has also felt different to the left for years. In 2014 the consultant completely reassured me and I felt like a bit of a fraud, taking up his time. He recommended oil of evening primrose. I think because of his reassurance I was not that vigilant about checking my breasts. Roll on 2 years, large lump and extensive spread to lymph, fingers crossed it hasn't spread any further. I have looked on some forums and people have commented that their cancers could have been growing for 1-2 years. I keep thinking now was this the start. I keep telling myself, even if it was the start, it is not going to make any difference now. Just cross, cross cross, mainly with myself. Wondering if anybody had any opinions/experience/thoughts on this?
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Thank you all for taking the time to write responses. I guess I do need to focus on the future and just look at moving forward. I am just scared that I did not find out in time and that it might not be treatable. That's why then I just wonder did I miss something in the past, was my body trying to tell me something and so on!!! Sigh, I am just going to settle down with cup of tea and some home made cake courtesy of my 18 year old son who is immensely proud of himself. Live in the present and try to take pleasure from little things. XXX
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Hi, I have been using bio oil on my face and on my mx scar. My skin did become drier on chemo and I found this helped. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Dry skin and eyes

Posts.Content: Lynn it's a great idea. I did bring the bike downstairs at the start of the year and I was trying to do about 15 mins a day. I was quite chuffed with myself, but then had a set back Feb/March time and haven't done anything since! Several times I have sat in the room where the bike is, and prepared lessons with netflix on in the background on my laptop. Now I am thinking a bit of cycling is o the cards with netflix on!  Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Hi Lemongrass, I remember after my first fec treatment, there was one night that I just couldn't get to sleep. In fact it got to 6/7am before I started feeling dozy, and as I had a full day ahead of family visiting I just got up and got on with it. I did mention this to my onc and he halved the dose of the steroids for the remaining sessions of fec. This worked fine and for the remaining fec sessions I was ok. It all changed on T. On T you have steroids before and after chemo. I did not get that 'sleeplessness' on T. Maybe because I was so completely knackered by that stage... :D Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Back to work anxiety

Posts.Content: Evening LL, Just wanted to say that I think that is a good idea too if you feel up to it in time. Maybe take a little time to get your head around it? Posts.Title: Today......

Posts.Content: Hi Wynneth,  Just wanted to add that I had an immediate implant reconstruction as well at the same time as surgery, then chemo and rads after. No one ever mentioned to me that a reconstruction worked best after chemo - it is the first time I have ever heard that mentioned. Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: Hi JustLittleMe, Just wondering if I could ask you a couple of questions? I teach too and although I might go in for a couple of weeks before the summer to sort things out (like put my room back to normal!), I am not thinking of going back properly until September - which is when I am thinking of a phased return. (I still have 4 weeks of radiotherapy to go through). I was just thinking that 3 weeks of reduced hours is not very long. Do you mind if I ask if you were ok with this or if you had any other options? Of course with teaching it is not just the hours in school, it is all the hours of marking and preparation that is done at home. I am worried that even if I make it through a full day when I return, I will not cope with the possible extra 2-3 hours a night! Also when I last went into school, my head of department mentioned the timetable allocation for next year. Basically she was saying that timetable-wise, it would be easier to allocate me a reduced number of lessons for the whole year with the implication being a reduced timetable would be reduced pay for the year!  One suggestion was possibly dropping to 0.7 allocation. Now I am really going to struggle when I go down to half pay in a couple of weeks, I don't need the added worry about not coping financially for another whole year. She wasn't being funny, she is lovely and very supportive but she wasn't sure how it works either. Just wondering about your experience. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Back to work anxiety

Posts.Content: Good luck for tomorrow JustLittleMe, hope it all goes ok. X
Posts.Title: Back to work anxiety

Posts.Content: Hi jsj, I preferred to wear sports bras rather than post surgery bras. I did not get a front fastening one but I remember after the op, I wished that I had! It was difficult lifting my arms up. and I remember getting stuck in one sports bra that you put on over the head - I was half in and half out - I had to call for help! Asda and tesco had a good selection. Asda also do lots of post surgery bras on line - they are not always in the shops. I just bought my normal size. I found it useful to wear a strappy top under a shirt. This was easy to peel down whenever I had appointments. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Recommendations on bras/ post op tops.

Posts.Content: Hi Pipsters,  I think I had a similar situation to KerryCake - I always expected bc would be a hard pea like lump. Mine too was more like a thickening of an area, not a definite hard lump. When I felt around for it, in some positions I could feel it and then in some positions I could not. Does one breast feel different from the other? Anyway definitely get yourself to the GP. Most appointments are only for 10 minutes so don't even worry about wasting someone's time. And if it gives you peace of mind, then it is not a waste. Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: finding lumps - some advice please

Posts.Content: Hi JammyR, I can't remember how soon it happened after the start of chemo but I did get strange tingly tight feeling of my scalp. Often described as having had your hair in a tight pony tail. I used the cold cap and kept quite a lot of hair - so you might be ok. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Itchy Scalp.

Posts.Content: Hiya, I am also a veggie. I asked my onc about soya containing foods and he said it was the first time he had ever been asked and wasn't really sure. Then I went on a breast cancer care course and they said that there was not enough evidence to suggest that soya containing foods were a problem. I have not cut soya out of my diet but I have instead have tried to have more quorn instead of soya. So when I have made spag bol, instead of using soya mince, I have used quorn instead. I still eat soya containing products but maybe not as often as I would have.  I also bought flaxseeds when I was first given my dx. Again I think the evidence is limited. Personally I think a little is ok .  As tox says, worrying about it is not good. Carry on trying to have a balanced, healthy diet.  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Scared and Anxious

Posts.Content: Hiya, I had fec-T. Three cycles of fec every 3 weeks followed by three cycles of T. I think it is the most common type.It was nowhere near as bad as I expected.  I had my first onc appt on 13th Dec and started chemo on 4th January.  It was delayed a bit because I had to have a ct scan and I then had a picc line fitted and also Xmas and New Year got in the way. I think it is generally two weeks after the start of chemo that hair loss happens. I used the cold cap myself. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Lots of questions!

Posts.Content: Hiya, Er+ve bc means that this type of bc is oestrogen receptive - the bc 'feeds off' the oestrogen in your body. Because of this you are likely to be offered hormone treatment to reduce the amount of oestrogen in your body. It might be tamoxifen or it could be an aromatase inhibitor such as letrozole.  Because of your age I would assume you are pre- menopause. This might means you are offered zoladex injections to stop your ovaries from making more oestrogen or that might even suggest ovary removal.  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: ER+

Posts.Content: Yes my daughter was happy too x
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Hi I went last week. Apparently £300 pounds worth of freebies - in a white bag that I managed to splash foundation on before I left. Definitely worth it if you have a spare couple of hours. Nice to have a chat. several ladies wore scarves or wigs and were comfortable to take them off. However I will say that after a few days of wearing skin stuff, my skin did develop a little rash. I think from the foundation. So I have put it to the side till after chemo all done Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Title: My Treatment Plan

Posts.Content: Hiya FBNDY, I had an ANC last November. My cancer was on the rightside and I am right handed too. In the summer I was at the gym regularly, running, weights (only small ones with my arms) and zumba classes. Also spa, sauna and steam room. All is good so far. I have kind of stalled a bit as I have gone back to work full time, but I still have my gym membership and I am going to start going back in Jan. Well, that's the plan anyway... Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi,  I can't comment on the other options but I had a picc and I was really pleased that I had it. The nurse came every week to flush it and change the dressing. After 3 months the dressings did start to irritate my skin though. Having a bath or shower is tricky because you shouldn't get it wet. However I would ask for one again if I needed to. Have they said that they will give you a choice? I think where I am that they usually go for the veins to start with. There needs to be a reason to go for another option. (My veins collapsed during a scan prior to chemotherapy). Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Cannula vs PICC vs Port??

Posts.Content: Hi just reread my post and thought it was not very clear! I have counted fec as 1,2 and 3. So T 4 was the first dose of docetaxol, and then T 5 was the second! Gay xx
Posts.Title: Mum starts Docetaxel soon for stage 3 breast cancer. Any advice ladies...

Posts.Content: Hiya lumie, I first had pain and my right breast felt thicker/heavier than the left side - reminded me of when milk comes in when breast feeding. A mammogram in 2014 was clear and I was sent away thinking everything was absolutely fine. I still had this heavy feeling for the next two years but felt secured because I had had it checked out and was told nothing to worry. :( Then in Oct 2016 I noticed my skin puckering in when I lifted my arm up - noticed it in the mirror when I was undressing for a bath. It didn't feel any different to me as it had felt heavier for the past two years but the GP felt a lump. I mainly had lobular cancer which is known to be a sneaky bugger and does not usually show up on a mammogram nor does it always present as a lump. I was surprised by this too.  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Recalled, Waiting, Worried

Posts.Content: Hi,  Just had my last T on Tuesday - just waiting for the tax truck to hit...lol! No please tell your mum not to worry- It hasn't been as bad as I was expecting having read all the horror stories. Not as easy as FEC was, but FEC was very kind to me.  My advice would be to pre dose on painkillers eg ibuprofen and codeine (check to make sure these are ok for her) after day 2. The aches for me left me feeling tender all over so a few days spent on settee. After T 4, I felt very sorry for myself and did lie down a lot. After T 5, I made an effort to be more active - a little walk everyday, and it did help. The feeling in my mouth was horrid - ice lollies and yogurts helped me. Both of these started about day 2/3 and lasted till day 8/9.   Just tell your mum to take it easy. If she does have any unpleasant side effects make sure she rings up and gets something to help for them. But it will be ok, and just keep thinking the end will be in sight. Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Mum starts Docetaxel soon for stage 3 breast cancer. Any advice ladies...

Posts.Title: I am blessed!!!

Posts.Content: Hiya Beedeb, The first few days after fec are the worse. I asked and was told that any over the counter medication was ok for indigestion but ring and check before your mum takes anything. I wouldn't think it should worsen. I told my onc about not sleeping very well after the steroids so for the second and third fec he halved the dose of the steroids. The dose will go up for the docetaxel though but I slept ok on that. Cwtches,  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Mum has started chemo...

Posts.Content: Hi lumie,  Welcome to the group. Not that anyone actually wants to be here... but we are a very friendly bunch!  Hmm, questions, questions! Firstly one thing I have learnt from when I was first diagnosed is that everyone is so different - so it is difficult to comment on the points you have made. I do know that in my case my cancer did not show on the mammogram and the US was inconclusive - the dr couldn't be sure one way or another. I had presumed that all cancers would show on a mammogram - this is not always the case. After surgery I have an area of scar tissue - again US of this was inconclusive. So it is not always the case that they can give you definite answers after mammograms/US. It does seem that they are being very thorough - which is a good thing (in my opinion).  A couple more things I need to mention to you. Firstly, think that worrying will not change the results. So try to keep yourself occupied and try not to worry - and yes, I have been there myself so I do know how hard this is. Secondly if it is bc, then it is very treatable and we will be here to hold your virtual hand. If you have anymore questions or if you just want to cry or rant, please feel free on here. Sending you cwtches, Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Waiting......

Posts.Content: Hi 4paws, Sounds as though the T truck has hit you! I had my second T on Wednesday, and I know it is now heading my way....T came as a bit of a shock after fec. My pains started 2/3 days after the first T, aching and tender all over. Back ache, headache, neck glands up, horrid taste etc, etc!! Lasted about another 5/6 days, so did get at least a week of normality before second dose. My temp also rose slightly to just above 37 degrees C, it was slightly lower on fec. Just try to think what it is doing to those nasty cancer cells. Next time pre dose on painkillers, paracetamol, ibuprofen, cocodamol etc - check with your onc what you can take and space out the doses. You could ring up your bcn to ask about back pains etc, but it does sound similar to my experience. Try to hang in there. Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel & Herceptin side affects

Posts.Content: Hi Lilythepig,  Do you have a dressing covering the end of the line? Not quite sure where you mean you are putting the cotton wool! I used tubigrip supplied by the hospital and the district nurse to go over the dressing. It does come in different sizes so doesn't need to be tight. Fortunately I had mine over the cold months so long sleeves covered it. Once when I was going out I did cut up a pair of patterned tights to wear over it - maybe you could try this at night time? You could even try cutting the foot of a sock off.  There are also picc line covers available on ebay or just type into google. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: PICC line - advice please

Posts.Content: Hiya Linkj, A wimp?? After all that you have been through in such a short period of time??? No way! This is just an old case of people not understanding or empathizing what it is like. It is unfortunate but generally people cannot even imagine what it is like (not even close) until they walk in the same shoes themselves. Not that anybody would wish this experience on anybody else.  It is always the case when you look ok on the outside - people are not aware of what is going on in the inside. I'm sure your friend did not mean any ill will, she does not understand. I get the same now I am back at work, everyone thinks I am back to normal (what's that???), but I am not. They don't see me collapsing on the settee at night. Even my close family see me back at work and think that I am ok. Well, I am not and I can't see I ever will be, but I will keep on plodding on, trying to do the best I can. Cwtches, Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Tigermum,  I had this, well actually still have this. For me , it is scar tissue, fat necrosis. I had to have US, an MRI scan and a biopsy to make sure that was what it was. Apparently quite normal after breast surgery, but get it checked out. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi, My wound healed up about 3-4 weeks afterwards. Depends how big/deep your 'scabs' are. I had one quite large one by my nipple which took longer to heal and finally drop off! I don't remember how long pain lasted. I am such a wuss, I kept the painkillers topped up. I heard it was easier to keep on top of the pain, rather than wait for it to appear and then take tablets. I would think you would be ok to take painkillers up to the weekend, but if in doubt check with your bcn.  I had full clearance when I had my mx last November. The numbness has got less and less as time gets on, but I still do have some slight numbness under my armpit at side of boob, and underneath the top of my arm. It is hardly noticeable (I just had a quick feel now to double check lol), but it is there and I am presuming I will always have some slight numbness.  keep on doing your exercises to help too. Take care, Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Found lump under arm 5 months after double mastectomy and lymph node...

Posts.Content: Hiya, My lump did turn out to be scar tissue. It was quite a worrying time though. The Dr did not initially want to take a biopsy sample because it was close to my implant. So back for a biopsy which the Dr did very carefully!!  All the waiting time in between was awful. But better to get it checked out. It is still there now. You can't see it. But I do check it to make sure it doesn't change in size or shape. Ring up again on Monday to get an appointment to get it checked out. And try not to worry, because worrying will not change the outcome. Cwtches, Gay xxx Strange username though.....

Posts.Title: Been diagnosed with cancer Oestrogen Sensitive her2 negative on 5th...

Posts.Title: What to take to hospital?

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a skin sparing mx with recon last November. In terms of bras, you need post surgery bras or sports bras. A front fastening bra (or 2) is a really good idea. I didn't have any, and I remember once getting trapped half in half out of a sports bra with a racer type back. (had to call other half for help). I personally prefer sports bras because they seem to fit better and mould to your shape. Post surgery bras don't  seem to fit my implant that well - that could just be me!! To begin with I just got a few sports bras from Asda, fairly cheap and did what they needed to do! You don't need any cream whatsoever for your wound. You need to keep it completely dry until the scar has heeled completely. It will take a few weeks.  Do take moisturiser for your skin. I had to get some brought in to massage my skin from advice from the lymphoedema nurse.(if you are having a full node clearance).  Trying to rack my brain to think of anything else to take in. I would suggest buying some dry shampoo, not necessarily to take to hospital but to have at home because I couldn't wash my hair properly for 2/3 weeks. Mind you, I ended up buying several cans, which are sat on a shelf now because I don't need them at the moment...... I was told to keep on top of the pain killers. I was given ibuprofen and co codamol.  I took them for about a week and had no issues with pain what so ever (did have constipation from the cocodamol, sorry if tmi).  Are you having a anc? I did. For 2/3 weeks I couldn't lift my arm above shoulder level. I could drive after 2/3 weeks, but mine was the right side, so I don't know about changing gears?  The main issue after surgery will be the drains that you have to carry around with you for about a week and have emptied. I was maybe a little bit tired, not much. I think how much you can lift depends on whether you are having an anc.  Have to go now, hope you found some of this useful. Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Initially I did not take my tablet because I did not realise that the hospital had free wi fi. I am glad I had a big fluffy dressing gown because they are quite stingy with the blankets. An eye mask sounds good, I didn't think of one of those. Maybe also earplugs because there is always at least one snorer!!! Lip balm or vaseline would have been handy because my lips got very dry - although the nurses found some for me when I asked. I also wish that someone had said wear 100% cotton knickers so I could have worn them during the op instead of having to wear horrible baggy paper things.   xxx
Posts.Title: What to take to hospital?

Posts.Content: That is the first time I have heard of a drain dollie! I got given 2 drain bags by my bcn and a mini heart shaped pillow. Mind you I did not get a free bra.... Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Happybird, Just want to say that I too am on letrozole and I do not have any bad side effects or pain. I did get aches in my fingers when I first started so I started to take glucosamine and omega 3 oil capsules and I find they really help. If ever I run out, the aches do slowly start to come back. They are quite expensive but they are worth it.  Like Cannon, I agree with finding a brand that suits and sticking to it. I use the accord brand - I read old posts and lots of people said it was ok. Mind you, I have not tried any other brands, I found that one and stuck to it. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I had to go to 4 pharmacies in 3 different areas yesterday trying to find one that had accord! I had a lecture from one pharmacist that all the brands were exactly the same, yeah right. Normally I pick up my prescription from my GP surgery and I hunt around to find a pharmacist that has accord, which I don't mind doing. Yesterday the GP surgery told me that I have to nominate a pharmacist to collect my prescription, I can't collect it from the surgery anymore, apparently health board rules. I protested saying I don't always go to the same chemist. Tough, they said After a 2 hour drive around, I found a nice pharmacist in the next town, who said that they could probably get accord for me. So I filled in the form for them to send to the surgery What a palaver! Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Letrozole: have Cipla really taken over Accord?

Posts.Content: I only get one month's supply as well. Very annoying when we are told to be on them for years!! Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Letrozole: have Cipla really taken over Accord?

Posts.Content: Hiya all, I have a letter from my bcn outlining my 5 year care plan. After my 2 year mammogram it says I should get a phone call from my bcn to discuss results. Instead I  have come home tonight to open an appointment with the consultant. Hmmm, things feel ok to me, but can't stop wondering if things are ok, then why have I been sent an appointment with the surgeon??? Just wondering how everyone else got their results? Sensible head is saying everything is ok, crazy head is saying what IF?, why send a consultant appointment if it is not necessary?? Think I will ring the consultant's secretary tomorrow to see if I can find out any more. Just wondering about everyone else's experiences?  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Second year mammo after, how did you get your results?

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic, Just wanted to say I am in the same boat and I understand exactly how you are feeling. I had mastectomy last Wednesday after noticing skin puckering on my breast on 2nd Oct. The doctor then pointed out to me where the lump was. I felt so stupid. How on earth did I not notice before? I got positive diagnosis on 10th November. As you say it happens so fast. It also has spread to my lymph nodes so had all them removed during the op. I don't know the grade or type yet, results should be on Monday. It is good to have these forums to know that others are going through/gone through what is happening to us now. My plan is just to take it one day at a time and maybe watch some naff christmas movies for the next month! Take care x
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: Hiya Charlie95, I could have written this myself 2 years ago. I was given a positive dx on 14th Nov 2016, op on 23rd Nov. I had back ache that I had never had before and I was convinced this was bad news. It wasn't. I think you are a lot more aware of things in your body that maybe you would not have normally noticed.  Keep posting, there are lots on here to listen and offer support. We are good at holding hands too, only virtually but it still counts. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Just got the dreaded c dianosis help

Posts.Content: Hmmm, fairly quiet on here too! Just thought I would say that I have not had any major issues with my implant. Recovery time was 3-4 weeks. You are having surgery anyway so you would just be knocked out for a little bit longer. My scar is lovely and neat. It goes from the side of my boob to the nipple and around the nipple. I kept the pain killers topped up so there was no issue with pain. I have not had any infections and no problems with radiotherapy. What have you been reading? Could it be that people have not posted about positive experiences and you have only read negative comments? Could you not get a reduction at the same time? Wishing you the best for making your decision, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Advice Please....Reconstruction or Not??

Posts.Content: Hiya, I did not get a report after surgery -you might get one if you ask.  The cold cap works fine with breast cancer chemo. It is more uncomfortable than painful. I did actually lose quite a bit, but I would use it again. Not heard of a tablet you can take. I didn't work through chemo as I work in a school and there would have been a high risk of infection but I did feel that maybe I could have coped, especially on the better days. People go on to have babies after breast cancer, don't lose hope. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Grade of Cancer changed after Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I always had mine done on the lower part of my arm, never on top of the picc line. Did they get a reliable reading? Did it hurt?  As long as it didn't hurt, I would think it should be ok. Check that you don't get a bruise from it in the next few days. Mind you on saying that, how did you feel? If you were not happy, tell them so! It doesn't matter what they do with others if you are not happy with it. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Blood pressure cuff and PICC line

Posts.Content: Forgot to add, I also have high blood pressure. There was a question when I went in for the pre op whether surgery would take place. It did take place, battle won - yay. Now bring on the war!
Posts.Title: Any advice

Posts.Content: Hi Tukis, Hope you are recovering gently from your surgery. I think it takes a while for the anaesthetic to wear off and that is one major op, so make sure you are being kind to yourself. I know what you mean about your worries - I am 44 and my children are teenagers but I still have had those thoughts too. When you had surgery, the nasty b*stard cancer cells were taken out. Chemo and radio will mop up any strays. Focus on being positive - try to put your worries to the back of your mind. Take it one day at a time, or even an hour at a time.  If you need to come on here and cry/rant/rage/ talk about crap, then do. There will always be someone here. I am halfway through chemo, slowly but surely getting there... Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling deflated

Posts.Content: Hiya Info19, Just some general answers to your questions. Once the cancer has spread from the breast, it is classed as stage 4. I think it likely that chemotherapy and radiotherapy could be treatment options. In order to ease her fears what is it in particular that she is fearful of?  Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are very different treatments. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Relationship between cancer spread, stage and treatment options

Posts.Content: Hi, I had mastectomy on 23rd Nov and my first chemo should be the second week in January. I would have liked to get started sooner but christmas and new year are in the way. Part of me thinks good, at least I can enjoy the festive period as much as I can, but then part of me thinks I just want to get it started! Overall I have decided that what will be, will be. I can't speed it up so there is no point worrying even if there is still a little niggle at the back of my mind - what if it is spreading even more! My veins have conspired against me so now I have to have a picc line fitted which has lead to the delay.  Take care and try to enjoy christmas, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Any advice

Posts.Content: Great news...carry on rocking :D Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Whoop whoop ... mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hiya, I loved my picc, well maybe liked it a lot :D... I had it in as my veins collapsed during a CT scan before chemo so I never went through chemo with a cannula. It made things so easy when for bloods and for chemo. I used to feel sorry for those sat there with their hands in buckets of water. The district nurse called up once a week to flush it through. I was given a shower cover (a limbo) because you cannot get it wet - a bit of a nuisance at times but I still would rather have had it than not.  I am not quite sure how I would have felt to have a picc line in the summer, but in the winter months it is covered up and no-one will know. (I had chemo Jan-April). Given a choice I would choose a picc line 100%, not that I hope to be ever in that position again. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: PICC line or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Zamzam, Just wanted to say that I used warm salt water to rinse my mouth several times a day and it helped me. Nice and cheap if you want to give it a try! Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Mouth pain - gum and teeth

Posts.Content: Hi Tukis,  Have a virtual ((hug)). I think you will find that lots of us are quite good at putting on a brave face for others, but on here you don't have to. I think that people without a diagnosis would not really understand. I have a stage 3, grade 2 diagnosis with lots of lymph involvement.  I don't think that my life will ever be the same again. But I am going to make sure that it changes for the better. For example, I am going to make more time for my children, I am cooking them more healthy meals, I am trying to make sure we are all getting our 5 a day, I am not going to let myself be absorbed in work issues (when I go back), I am going to try and do more exercise, I will always text my mum back when she texts me etc, etc. All little things but things that I have control over. This gives me something to focus on. I have read your post in the under 50s group. Have you had your surgery yet? Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling deflated

Posts.Content: Couldn't believe it today - went flying literally. Why put a stupid f in curb in the middle of a car park!!!!! Several steps, I could feel myself going. Sat on the floor feeling very sorry for myself. Thank you to the lots of people who came to my aid. First time I felt older than my years,  got a feeling I need to get used to it. Was my head fuzzy, I don't know. Sore knee, sore arm, wonky boob and bad back. Come on 2017, you will be better. xxx
Posts.Title: went flying...

Posts.Content: Hi, Just wondering if one of those v shaped pillows might help. It might elevate her upwards a bit, so she could rest easier on her back. I know a certain well known website selling items for cancer patients sells them. Just an idea. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Any tips on ways to get some sleep after lumpectomy?

Posts.Content: Hiya, My biopsy didn't hurt really but I didn't like the noise - it sounds like a staple gun! Gay xxx

She has been texting me as she cruised across the Atlantic (!) asking me about Strictly and the jungle so I am quite sure she has no idea whatsoever! I just wish I was closer to give her a big hug. ronstar - is there a number for my mum to contact macmillan or a webpage?  Thanks again x

Posts.Content: Oops! There's me asking about a phone number... and there it is in big green numbers at the bottom of the page! D'oh. Not always thinking straight at the moment! x
Posts.Title: Telling mum

Posts.Content: Hi, I was just wondering if anyone had any advice on how to tell my mum who lives 400 miles away. My sister, age 50, passed away in March (not cancer related) and I am really worried about how my mum will take all of this, especially as I am so far away. Since March we have become closer, in contact everyday. I think I will use Skype so she can see me, but I am not sure how to announce it. I don't want to sound blase but nor do I want to worry her. I had biopsy on 10th Nov, news on 14th and Mx on the 23rd. I haven't told her any of this because she has just been away on a big holiday which after everything that happened with my sister, I think she needed. She knows that I had a lump and that I had a mammogram at end of October. However I had a mammogram a couple of years ago because I had constant pain in my breasts and I had the all clear then. I told her that I had a routine recall because I had a mammogram before. Just before she went away, she asked if I had heard anything and I told her no. She is blissfully unaware at the moment. She is flying in today and has texted me that she will ring tomorrow. Don't want to tell her any more fibs!

Posts.Title: Aching bones with Letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi Winky49, No magic answers, just thought I would tell you about my experiences. Since I started taking letrozole last July, I have made a conscious effort to stick to one brand, accord. Sometimes this means that I have to go to several different chemists to get my prescription. I found the side effects quite bad to start of with, achy fingers, achy bones - especially first thing in the morning, I describe it as the robot (the movements I made getting up and walking down the stairs!) I found that taking a joint supplement really helped. I took seven seas glucasamine + omega 3 tablets, quite pricey but were worth it. Available in all supermarkets, but also in some bargain stores, like home bargains. Now several months later I have stopped taking supplements. Not actually by choice initially, I ran out and kept forgetting to get more in! I thought at first I would not be able to cope, but everything is ok. I still have achy fingers but not that bad, I am just aware of it as a mild ache. I take my tablets at night before I go to bed, I would suggest you try sticking to one brand for a few months. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Aching bones with Letrozol

Posts.Content: Hiya, I think I replied to your earlier posts. Sorry you got a positive dx but as you said you have done it all before and we are all with you this time! Gay xxx
Posts.Title: I have just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hiya, I also had this op Feb 18. I was off work for two weeks as they recommend not to drive for 2 weeks. Quick easy op with minimal recovery time.Only a couple of days after with strong painkillers. I had 4 small incisions, one in my belly button, 2 each side where ovaries are and one just above pubic hair line. They are so small that no one would notice them unless I pointed them out. I was on zoladex for about 6 months beforehand. Immediately after the op, I did have more hot flushes than before but they soon subsided.  Cwtches,  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Ooverectomy

Posts.Content: Oh my lovely, what an awful position for you to be in.  You and your brothers are her next of kin (I assume), if they are all in support of you, then my opinion is go for it and take her home to your house. I am sure your mum if she was aware of what was happening would want the best for you too. You cannot please everybody. I think that this is a selfless action, the complete opposite of being selfish.  What is the problem with her brother and sisters? Are any of them wanting to take her into their homes? Even if they said yes, the views of her children are more important  - in my opinion.  It is difficult for me to comment on this because as a member of the bc group, I have had bc myself, not that I have cared for somebody. Although my mum has had bowel cancer, she is ( fingers crossed) doing ok - awaiting scan results. Maybe if you posted in the carers group, you might find more people that have been in a similar position? Sending you lots of cwtches, do what you think is best for your mum. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Mum's Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Googieswife, Just wanted to comment on your op tomorrow. My mx was my first time in surgery too, since then I had my ovaries out on 15th Feb this year. Both times I was petrified, not just because of what the op entailed but the thought of being put to sleep. My main advice here is to make sure the staff know how you are feeling (if you are worried about the op) I was quietly sobbing in a tissue as I walked down into the op theatre with the nurse. All the staff were kind, patient and calming. They did not rush me. I had an injection of something - don't know what - because I was upset and anxious. Anyway it obviously worked I don't even remember going to sleep! I don't remember having this injection when I had my mx. But I would recommend it! Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: New and scared!

Posts.Content: Hi, For me - hair growth very, very very slowly. Eyebrows thinned, eyelashes went.  Not particularly joint pain, but flu-type ache all over. Like you feel very tender, as though you are covered in invisible bruises - that's why they say hit by the tax truck! It is a very weird feeling. Easily managed by taking painkillers. Ibuprofen and paracetamol taken alternatively over 2 hours, obviously keeping within the daily limit. I did have some cocodamol left over from surgery so I had that for the first one. With fec, I was fine, with T, I had a couple of days each cycle on the settee. Effects lasted from about day 2 to 10. The day after chemo, I was fine - I thought what's all the fuss about..... I put weight on during fec as I did a lot of comfort eating. With T the taste in my mouth was so foul. I actually started to lose weight on T.  The good news is that by the first time you notice the effects of the first T, you will be able to say to yourself that you have nearly finished chemo, the end will be in sight.  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Truth about doxetaxel

Posts.Content: I am also far too scared to know. I just think that it might get me down and I am trying to be as positive as I can. Maybe after I have had further treatment but at the moment I just cannot face it.  xxx
Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Hi Winky49, My onc ordered the dexa scan, but I was told when I had the scan that my results would be with the GP in two weeks. And they were. Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hiya, I used nioxin hair care system earlier in the year. It seemed to work ok, but I can't compare it to what it would have been like without it, if that makes sense! Someone at work asked me if I have had a perm! Just a quick comment about nails - mine are all breaking, they seem quite weak. :(  I am on letrozole too. Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Should I find another group?

Posts.Content: Hi, I asked my bcn this about 6 months after surgery. She said it was fine for me to wear underwired bras now. However I have found that some underwired bras don't ft around my implant very well and just don't look right.  And during that six months I bought quite a few nice soft non-wired bras. So basically now I wear a mixture of both soft bras and some underwired ones which fit ok. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Bras and implants

Posts.Content: Hi The six month time was when I was having chemo and radio so I did not talk to my bcn during that time. So it might be a case that you can wear underwired bras sooner if you want to check! Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Bras and implants

I have seen several ladies with large tumours, I think the biggest one I have seen was about 12cm. As tox says, there are lots of other things that also are considered. Cwtches, Gay xxx

Posts.Content: twinkle79, Any changes in your breasts should be checked. Hopefully it is nothing but is it worth the risk? It obviously bothered you enough to seek out this site. I first noticed my skin puckering in when I lifted my arms up. I could not feel a definite lump but my boob did feel 'heavier'. Please get this checked out. Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a nipple sparing and skin sparing mx last November. I wasn't actually sure until I took the dressing off whether I would still have a nipple or not..but needless to say I did! Never been so pleased to see my nipple. In my case, I have pretty much no sensation in my nipple. I guess it was more for the looks value. Gay xxx P.S keep roaring! Reminds me, once I had a rabbit called Tiger x

Posts.Title: Happy new year?

Posts.Content: Hi maxinem2, I also had dx in Nov 2016. I last saw my onc (well, actually one of his minions) in April this year and she told me she had no idea why this appointment had been made and that I should have been discharged the previous year. Posts.Title: Two years since Chemo what now

Posts.Content: Hi, Some of the effects you mention (sweating, clammy, fatigue, trouble sleeping ) could be linked to the menopause which chemo can bring about. I think I have read some ladies who have been through the menopause previously, have symptoms again on chemo. I had not gone through the menopause and I certainly noticed some of these effects. Nausea - drs can prescribe tablets for this, try emend. I found travel sickness wrist bands from boots helpful. Funny mouth and taste - again there is a mouthwash that can be prescribed. I found gargling with warm salt water helped. Yogurt and ice lollies helped. This is definitely one thing that got worse as treatment went on. And look through the awake thread where there are lots of pics to keep you amused :D. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Effects of chemo EC90

Posts.Content: Hello there zizza,  Welcome to the group, although I am sorry that you had  to come and find us.  I know what you mean about those panicky feelings inside. I found that telling myself over again that 'worrying will not change the results' helped to calm me down. I think I got it from a post I saw on here, I think it might have been written by mistymoley. I often use it myself now in posts I write. I am now post active treatment but I am on zoladex injections and letrozole. I find that at times I still get that anxious, panicky feeling. Now I have to tell myself not to worry about things that are out of my control - I can't change them. Getting quite good at giving myself a good talking to - don't worry I don't do it out loud :D Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy result - just need to vent

Posts.Content: Hiya, It took about 3 months for my lashes and brows to come back. My bottom lashes came back first.  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Last chemo & hair regrowth

Posts.Content: Hi Batfinkcaz,. I am not even sure that it should be called a 'needle' - it is not a needle like the one most people think of! I have found the pain level very much depends on who does the injection. I have had three different nurses inject me. I have had 5 so far. A couple I could hardly feel, one hurt A LOT and the other two were ok. I always find that the male nurse is more gentle! I had heard somewhere about anaesthetic cream being applied to the tummy before the injection. When I went for my first injection, I mentioned it to the nurse and he said that it could be prescribed but one had not been prescribed for that session as it was my first one. I said I would see how it went. As this first one was ok, I said I wouldn't bother with any anaesthetic in future. So it can be ordered. Why don't you ring up the onc unit and ask for anaesthetic to be prescribed for when you have the next injection? I wouldn't leave it until you went in, because it might need to be prescribed.  Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hi, Why does it seem very likely? I was fine throughout fec - I questioned my onc was it working because I didn't have many side effects! Can't see any reason why it should be different the next time! If you are then having T, that's a different kettle of fish... Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Am i feeling too normal?

Posts.Title: Breast pain after taking zolodex?

Posts.Content: Hello there, Welcome to the group. It can be rather surreal when you are first diagnosed - especially as with breast cancer you don't generally feel ill. Did they confirm the diagnosis on the phone? I think that is unusual - it is normally done in person. I am guessing you have an appointment now to discuss treatment options? It is a bit pants at first because there is quite a bit of waiting for results, appointments, etc. But bc is very treatable and there are lots of us on her to answer any questions you may have. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer at 50

Posts.Content: Hi Cbr55, Get yourself  GP appointment as soon as you can or have you still got bcn details?. Everybody should check out any changes with their breasts.It doesn't matter if it is nothing, you need to do it for your peace of mind. Whenever I feel nervous about doing something, I give myself a little pep talk - inside my head of course! Remind yourself of all the treatment you have gone through. You have faced cancer, you can face some passing glances etc. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Paranoid.

Posts.Content: I too have been rather shocked at some of the posts on this thread. There is just no need.  Looks like we need more bunnies.... Gay xxx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hiya Minksy and unicorn12,  Following on from what weeblemum has said about thinking about your worries for only 30 mins. You imagine all your worries in a box in your mind. The box opens up for only 30 mins a day. After that you have to imagine shutting the box up, and if it starts to open again, you have to tell yourself to keep it shut till the next day. Be firm with yourself!! I also want to tell you both that chemo was nowhere near as bad as I was expecting. I pretty much sailed through fec, no nausea, nothing (I swear by my anti nausea travel bands). There were a few days afer each T chemo that I was under the weather, but to be honest when you are at that stage the end is in sight and you know you are nearly there. I did not work as I work in a school and schools can be pretty germy places, but I think I could have done, especially on fec. One other thing that I used to keep saying to myself during those worrying waiting times, was that worrying about things will not change the outcomes - this did help me calm down.  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Terrified of starting chemo

Posts.Content: Hiya Minksy and unicorn12,  Following on from what weeblemum has said about thinking about your worries for only 30 mins. You imagine all your worries in a box in your mind. The box opens up for only 30 mins a day. After that you have to imagine shutting the box up, and if it starts to open again, you have to tell yourself to keep it shut till the next day. Be firm with yourself!! I also want to tell you both that chemo was nowhere near as bad as I was expecting. I pretty much sailed through fec, no nausea, nothing (I swear by my anti nausea travel bands). There were a few days afer each T chemo that I was under the weather, but to be honest when you are at that stage the end is in sight and you know you are nearly there. I did not work as I work in a school and schools can be pretty germy places, but I think I could have done, especially on fec. One other thing that I used to keep saying to myself during those worrying waiting times, was that worrying about things will not change the outcomes - this did help me calm down.  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Terrified of starting chemo

Posts.Content: I'm sorry if this is a bit stupid. I am sure I could look this up but not sure where. Could someone explain to me how I go about sending someone a private message? Apologies if this has been a post before. I did try but didn't seem to get anywhere - or may be I am a bit thick!
Posts.Title: making friends

Posts.Content: Hi Violet blue, I had a skin sparing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction using an implant in November. I only had 9 days between diagnosis and op so if I am perfectly honest I was shell shocked at the time and went along with what my consultant recommended. I remember the breast care nurse showing me photos. I did consider if I could cope without a breast and I was not totally against the idea. I think that because of my age (43) and the fact that I was a fairly small size (34A/B) the consultant considered an implant was the way to go. And now? Well I have to say that overall I am pleased with the outcome. My boobies are not perfect, but then they were not perfect before!!! I like the fact that I can wear a bra/bikini/swimming cossie and no-one would have any idea. There are lots of pretty post surgery bras around so you can still feel feminine. Without the bra, well I am a bit lopsided , my implant sits a bit higher up than my natural breast.  The scar on my breast is healing up nicely, it goes across from the side and around my nipple. I was not sure if I would still have my nipple - never been so pleased to see a nipple when they took the dressings off!!! If I had a choice, I would definitely have an implant again.  Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Choosing a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Kerry, It was 12 days after surgery that I had my results. It has tickled me the thought of people having a favourite boob! I never considered this Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Choosing a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Anniekz, I used the coldcap throughout 3 fec and 3 docetaxel. I lost quite a bit of hair on my second treatment of fec. I did not lose much hair at all on docetaxel - I have never heard anyone mention that it doesn't work all that well with it. (It was my eyebrows and eyelashes that went on T).  I did notice it becoming more painful as it went on as my hair got thinner and thinner. However for T, it does not need to stay on as long. I took both paracetamol and ibuprofen before the last two sessions - and this helped a lot. I did end up losing quite a bit of hair, but I would use it again, so I consider it a success. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a skin sparing mx with immediate implant reconstruction - and I kept my nipple! I wasn't sure it was still there till I peeled away the dressing - yay, never been so pleased to see my nipple ;D I didn't get a choice of what I wanted. I only had 9 days between dx and surgery so it was a bit of a whirlwind! I do wonder if it was because I was a size 10 that there would not be enough fat there - but I am only guessing. (There would probably be enough fat there now!!!) Anyway just to say that overall I am quite pleased with my implant. It is a nice shape and certainly in my bra/bikini, no one would ever know. I went on to have radiotherapy and have had no problems. I have a tiny area of hard scar tissue but I think that this could happen after any surgery. I am not aware that I will need anymore surgery in the future.  Good luck making your decision, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Advice with reconstruction: implants verus DIEP

Posts.Content: Hiya, Welcome to the forum. Sorry to hear about your dx but we are all a friendly bunch and there are lots of us on here for support, advice or the odd virtual hug! It is normal not to cry ... and it is normal to cry bucket loads. Everybody reacts differently. Usually with bc, most people don't feel ill, and  it can all be a surreal experience. I didn't really believe it at first, even now pretty much one year on, I look back and think did that all happen to me?  Fortunately bc is very treatable and treatment is do-able. Do you have any details yet of your treatment plan? Are they planning surgery first?  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed today with Breast Cancer at 31

Posts.Content: Hi everybody Just wanted to say don't worry too much about your weight at this time. Your body is going through enough as it is. There will be plenty of time after chemo to lose weight if that is what you want. The last thing that you should be worrying about is your weight. Get through chemo, get your body recovered and then think about your weight. I put on about a stone and a half during surgery and chemo. This really peed me off as I had spent the past year losing it! However once I started radio, I found it easier to get back to my routine and I started to lose it again. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hi JoDec, Personally I kept things as light hearted as I could with my children, then aged 15 and 18. We joked about having a free boob job and brazilian on the nhs. They were fine because they could see I was fine. The few meltdown moments I had, I made sure they weren't there to witness. My daugher was in her GCSE year so I did not want her worrying. We lost my sister earlier in the year so I didn't want them thinking they were going to lose me. My mum lives 4 hours away. I told her over skype so she could see me. Looking back I just blurted it out - I wonder now if I should have built it up a bit to maybe soften the blow. Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Nanny Jan, I had a bad lingering cough for about 4 weeks - it has just about gone now, but still cough every now and again. Posts.Title: Xmas

Posts.Content: Hi, I am fairly certain that they can't get rid of you. You are protected, ''  In England, Scotland and Wales, employees with cancer are protected from discrimination in the workplace by the Equality Act 2010. '' This is anybody with cancer or who has had cancer. You cannot be discriminated or treated unfairly just because you had cancer. There is a Macmillan booklet but I don't know how to tag it.  If you are signed off till August, then I would say you don't necessarily have to be in touch till the end of July when you could go in to discuss your return to work and how they could support you then eg by a phased return. If you have a good relationship you could get in touch, but you don't have to.  The most important thing here is don't worry about work. You have enough on your plate. Just concentrate on taking a bit of time to get yourself better.  The Macmillan helplne will have further info and may be able to reassure you some more. Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Worlds Biggest Coffee Morning

Posts.Content: Hi, My appointment for fec 3 yesterday was at 1pm and I left the hospital at about 2.45pm. 30 mins for cold cap to begin with, 20-30 min for actual chemo injected using a syringe by the nurse and then 45 mins for the cold cap to finish with. If you are not having the cold cap, then I don't think it will take that long at all. For my first one I took a big bag with book, magazine, tablet, water, snacks etc and hardly touched any of it! However I guess it might depend on how big/busy your hospital is. This was for the highest dose fec too. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: How long do Chemo treatments take?

Posts.Content: Hi Cartwheels, Are you moving onto T next? With T, you don't need to keep the cold cap on as long as for fec. I did 30 min before, 30 min during treatment and 20 min after during T. I lost at least 50% of my hair overall. Two weeks now after last chemo and it has started to grow back slowly. I too went very, very thin on top of my head and on my neck, mainly on one side! I think it was on my 4th chemo session, I noticed the difference with my very thin hair and how cold I felt. I was ready to not to it again. Like you said, I couldn't get warm all night. I went to bed with my socks on and a beanie hat that night! My teeth were chattering! Before the 5th and 6th session I took both paracetamol and ibuprofen and I coped much better. I also made sure I took more layers with me in my bag to put round me in case I needed them.  My hair to be honest looks pretty awful at the moment, but I am glad that I used the cold cap. I wear headbands and scarves to disguise the thin bits. I am pretty sure that with the scarves, it is not obvious to people who don't know me. I am not comfortable going out without the head scarves at the moment but I will get there! Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hiya, I think that if it causing you to worry and feel anxious then it is not ok. I assume it is making you feel bad because otherwise you would not have sought out this site. Go back to your GP and tell him how upset this is making you feel. Make sure you tell him that at times you think it feels different. You could always ask for a non-urgent referral to the breast clinic. I don't know if he then has to do this. If not,ask him again for further reassurance. Make sure your GP is aware of how you are feeling about your mum too.  If you are still not happy ask to see a different GP. Most do turn out to be fatty lumps, so try not to worry.  Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Hi I am using the cold cap. I have had 5 sessions now. I don't think my caps to begin with fitted that well and I have lost an awful lot of hair. But I am glad I have persevered. I didn't find it that painful until session 4 when my hair was so thin. I have a strip of thinness across the top of my head that I disguise with thick stretchy headbands. Also lost a lot at top of neck, but I have some hair that covers over it.  I did have shoulder length hair to begin with. I had it cut shorter but didn't go for pixie. Glad now because I would not have had any longer bits to cover up the patches. I still have my fringe. I found session 2 by FAR the worse for hair loss using the cold cap and I think that others have said that too. Be warned, it is very upsetting. Take care,  Gay xxx

Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi JennyEm,  I haven't really noticed any fatigue during chemo. The only thing that has affected me is not being able to sleep when on the steroids the couple of days around treatment, so this had knocked my sleeping pattern out. I am pretty sure that I could have coped with going into work, but as I teach I thought it best to stay away from any possible sources of infection. But I have managed to design some work booklets at home and I have also tried to do more exercises. The vast majority of days on chemo I have felt my normal self, achy after T but painkillers help. I had 3 fec, then 3 T, 3 weeks between each one.  I also used the cold cap with some success. I have lost a lot of hair probably about 50% but I am still glad I used it. When you are about to lose hair, the general feeling is like you have had your hair in a tight pony tail all day - it wasn't what I would describe as pain. I am hoping no more hair is going to go, I had last chemo on Tues. Of course everyone is different. Don't read too many horror stories. It has been nowhere even near as bad as I was expecting it to be. Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Everything tastes awful!

Posts.Content: Hi Dizzy17, I agree with weeblemum ask what you can take. The cold cap does not necessarily cause headaches, it is just bloody, bloody cold - paracetamol can take the edge off the coldness. I was ok to begin with without taking any paracetamol, but on my 4th chemo, the coldcap was so painful because by then my hair had thinned quite a bit. I managed the 5th and 6th chemo with paracetamol and high strength ibuprofen taken half an hour before the start of the chemo.  D you suffer from headaches regularly? If you do, then it might be a good idea to take something beforehand. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl34. I had zoladex injections for about 7-8 months before I had my ovaries removed. My bc was highly er+ and I had a high number of lymph node involvement so my onc didn't want any oestrogen knocking around. As I am 45, I was premenopause, so therefore my ovaries would still have been producing oestrogen. The zoladex puts a stop to the ovaries making oestrogen. It is a preventative measure. It is not the nicest of injections as the needle is quite big, so it is best not to look. I found that it really depends on the nurses giving the injection, some nurses, I couldn't feel a thing. But there were a couple of nurses, where it hurt quite a bit. Didn't put me off though, as I knew it was necessary to stop this shitty disease from coming back. I have now had my ovaries removed so I do not need any more injections. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Zoladex help plz

Posts.Content: Hi ambertiger, Welcome to the online forum. We are a very friendly bunch - even though none of us would actually want to be here! I actually can't help you much with your question but did want to welcome you on board. Posts.Title: Post surgery advice

Posts.Content: Hi, I also had an implant. I had a skin sparing mx with immediate implant and I kept my nipple - a nice surprise! (I wasn't sure and I didn't even think to ask as I only had 11 days between dx and op) I wasn't offered a diep, I don't think that I had enough belly fat to fill a breast either - although I have got a bit more belly now :(  I am not aware of any potential dangers of implants and no-one has mentioned further surgery in the future. I had chemo and radiotherapy after surgery - no changes to the implant. I have got a tiny little lump next to my implant which is scar tissue but I think this can happen after any op.  In a bra/bikini no-one can tell the difference. The implant is a bit perkier than my real breast, they don't call it a barbie boob for nothing!! Maybe someone with a diep will come along to give their opinions now but I am very happy with my implant. Gay xxx
