Posts.Title: DCIS - DIEP or implant reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi LL, Aarh the dreaded 'what ifs?'.  They occur in everyday life once in a while, but for us lot, I think it is fair to say they can be a common occurrence. If only there was a magic pill to banish them from our thoughts... I know you have lots of ideas what to do to keep busy - I have read your suggestions to other people. So act on your advice! The main thing I would add is to take advantage of the weather. It is lovely and sunny here and you are not that far away so hope it is the same for you. Get out, go for a walk. I presume the sea is not that far away from you? Sea air makes me feel good especially on a good day. Must be my Blackpool upbringing! :). If not, a nice local park? Go with a friend if you can, if not go on your own. Treat yourself to a '99'. Fresh air might mean you get a better night's sleep too. It has been said before but worrying is not going to change your results. So if anything pops in your head, tell yourself you are not going to think about it. I know how difficult it is. Same with getting your results. Tell yourself it is out of your control, there is nothing you can do so be firm with yourself and tell yourself not to think about it. Imagine redecorating your room, what would you have done? A new clothes wardrobe, what would you buy? I don't know if books/ magazines help. Personally I find it hard to concentrate on anything new, but I have gone back and reread books I have enjoyed in the past, more slowly this time, finding out minor details I missed the first time round! Don't know if any of this helps, but have a ((cwtch)) from me. One of those always helps. Take care,  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi Knicnic, I agree worrying is not going to change anything so no matter how difficult it is, try and put it in a box, shut the lid and put it to  the back of your mind for Christmas.  There are lots of supportive people on here that will readily answer any questions you might have. Whatever the outcome, your mum is in good hands and there are lots of treatments etc and lots of people to offer support, so please try not to worry. And yes, I do realise that it not always that easy. Take care, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Breast lump over 50

Posts.Content: Hiya mumofboys, Definitely ask for a referral. I also did not have a lump initially and when I first went to the breast clinic when I had pain in my breasts, I was told all was well, no problems. Two years later I was dx with stage 3 bc with significant spread to the lymph nodes. I believe myself that this started when I first went. I noticed changes in my breasts and I went away thinking all was well. My type of bc did not show up on a mammogram. Any changes in your breasts please get it checked out. And whatever they say, please be vigilant in future. You know your body, you will be the first one to notice any changes.  Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Can I ask you opinions?

Posts.Content: Hiya, I lost quite a bit, in a band across the top of my head after my second fec. And also at the back of my head - on one side only! I think it must have been where the cap did not fit very well. I used to comb over my hair on top and I had bob length hair at the back that covered over the back.  Could it have been that the cap did not fit very well the last time? I would still use it again tomorrow, if I was you. Only one more time.  I did end up having my hair cut fairly short afterwards as it ended up all different lengths and wasn't in the best condition. But I never lost it all. What is really odd is that even though I didn't lose it all, it is now full of curls when it was poker straight! Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Hair or no hair ,

Posts.Content: Yep all nodes gone on right hand side on the 23rd. Sounds like you are in the same place as me - just waiting and waiting and waiting! The fact that the nodes were involved was probably the most scariest thing. Again can't really offer reassurance - I guess everyone's case is different anyway, but you are not alone. I know it is difficult but try to stay calm and is there anything you can do to take your mind off it? Try and put it to the back of your mind and concentrate on other things. I hope this doesn't sound too harsh, it is what I am trying to do. I have lots of new books, xmas decs are up earlier than usual and I think I will start wrapping pressies up next week, a few at a time. Tomorrow I have a meeting planned with betty crocker - my son can't wait!!! x
Posts.Title: Worrying again

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4, I am still about too. Really pleased to hear from you and to hear that things are going well. Well, not that it is raining in Wales...but not so much of a change there! I am also back at work - it is half term next week for me. I can't wait. It hasn't been easy, but I have been so glad to be back at work - back to the real me. I think the odd worry worms of recurrence may always be there, but we can't live our lives worrying about that. Cwtches, Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hi I had a skin sparing mastectomy. Basically a cut from the side of the breast just by my arm, all the way across and round the bottom of nipple. I presume they then peeled all the skin back, scooped all the insides out and popped in an implant all at the same time! It is a gel/saline based implant. I wasn't given the option of using my own tissue. I am a size 10 so there is not that much spare fat (there is some though!) but I was not given this as an option. I was not sure that I would still have all my nipple but it still looks intact, all be it a little sorry for itself!!! I only had a positive diagnosis on the 14th Nov and the operation on the 23rd so I did not really have much time to consider all the options available. I did think mentally that I could handle no reconstruction but the surgeon seemed to think that because of my age (43) it would be better to have one at the same time. I had the drain for 10 days. I had it removed on the 5th Dec. There was still quite a bit of fluid there though, so I have to go back to hospital tomorrow to be drained if necessary! I think by way of an injection.  Hope this helps.  Gay xxx
Posts.Title: No radiotherapy now mastectomy and ANC

Posts.Content: Hi Lyndsey, I had a skin sparing mastectomy on 23rd Nov with an immediate reconstruction and ANC. All happened very quick, a slot came available so I went for it, just wanted the cancer OUT!!! I wasn't really given many options to consider, to be honest I was just so shell shocked I just went ahead with everything that was advised. The surgery was about 2 hours long. The most unpleasant thing is the drain that you carry around with you and sleeping with it is very uncomfortable. My new breast does feel very odd to touch. But it feels good to have all my skin (and my cleavage) and I think all my nipple still intact. I am pretty sure that I would be able to wear a swimsuit/bikini eventually and no-one would know. It is all just healing at the moment. Under my arm is still quite numb and I am finding that a lot of my clothes irritate me around this area. I have daily exercises to do and my arm is still a bit stiff. I can't do movements above shoulder level yet- getting dressed can be tricky and I need help to wash my hair at the moment. Not sure if this has answered any of your questions. If you want to ask anything else please post again and I will tell all from my experience or send me a private message. Take care, Gay x
Posts.Title: No radiotherapy now mastectomy and ANC

Posts.Content: Hiya, Welcome to the forum - a good place to share all your worries and concerns. Plus we are very good at hugs, cwtches and holding hands to appointments - only virtually, but it still counts! Now take some deep breaths. I think there are two main things to say here. Firstly worrying will not change the results. Be kind to yourself and try to keep busy and keep your mind occupied. Get out, go for a lovely walk, cinema, catch up with friends. Try to put the worries in a box in the back of your mind, and recognise the worries are there, but you are not opening that box today.  Secondly beast cancer is very treatable. There are lots of different treatments options and your treatment will be tailor made for you. The fact that they are doing scans means that they are being thorough - which has to be a good thing. I think it is best to know everything at the start so you will get the right treatment for you. Go enjoy a lovely Sunday with your husband and children. Gay xxx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, Yes, you will definitely feel better when you have a treatment plan in place. Waiting for results is the worse time, I think. However it normally doesn't take that long for results - even though it may feel like it! Gay xxx

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy planning appointment

Posts.Content: Hiya Charlene70 and Jojoboobs,  Firstly, both of these drugs affect different people in different ways. There is no point worrying about possible side effects - when they might not happen to you. Remember people often use online sites like this when they want advice and support. A person doing great with no side effects would not necessarily bother to post.  Personally I am on letrozole, I was on zoladex for several months and just over a week ago had my ovaries out. In my case, studies show that letrozole is the best choice for someone in my situation who had lots of lymph involvement, a large tumour and lobular bc. Everybody's bc is different, your team will suggest that you take the best one for YOU in your circumstances. Of course you don't have to take it and you can ask for alternatives. I found with letrozole that I have a few side effects - achy fingers, few hot flushes - but all mild, nothing I can't cope with. The side effects were more noticeable to begin with and they settled down. I make sure that I always stick to the same brand - can be a nuisance at times because pharmacies don;t always keep the same brands in stock. Different brands can affect people differently so if I start having problems, I will consider changing brands. I also have the choice of changing to other aromatase inhibitors eg anastrozole or exemestane. So there are different options.  Tamoxifen and letrozole have many similar side effects - menopausal ones!! However letrozole also causes bone thinning (may lead to osteoporosis) and more joint pain, more cholesterol and for me it has increased my blood pressure (so I now take tablets to reduce it!!) Tamoxifen on the other hand increases bone strength and may reduce cholesterol.  (Tamoxifen can also have different side effects but they are rare). I don't think either of you had chemo, so therefore on balance it might seem that tamoxifen is the best option or at least it seems that is what you both have been offered??? Oestrogen is also produced by other cells in your body so even if your periods have stopped, there will still be some present  - no idea of how much without looking it up. Cwtches,  Gay xxx

Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi, I had mastectomy and immediate recon in November. I only had 9 days from positive diagnosis to op so I went through it all in a sense of shock. I agree with lots of the comments here. A front fitting bra is a good idea - I did at one point get stuck trying to take off a sports bra that fitted rather too sugly at the back, had to call other half for help. Front opening pjs, dressing gown, eye mask, lip balm, moisturising lotion, kindle all needed.  My biggest fear was the anaesthetic as I had never had one before. The hospital staff are wonderful and they are used to dealing with it. I got a shock as I walked into the theatre room and saw all the lights etc - I thought I would be put to sleep in another room and then wheeled in! But as I say all staff were wonderful and were reassuring.  After the anaesthetic wore off later that night, I had no issues with mobility. Just had to make sure the drain leads don't get caught anywhere! Pain killers took all pain away. I am overall pleased with my new booby - although it is a bit more pert than the other one! Take care, I'll be thinking off you. Gay xxx

Posts.Content: Just reread my post. I had no issues with mobility in terms of walking around, however I couldn't lift my arm up above my shoulders. This lasted for about 3 weeks. I had plenty of dry shampoo because I couldn't wash my hair as I did normally. Just over 6 weeks post surgery and my arm is more or less back to normal. xxx
